Expectation1: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation1: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Situation2: They are listed as the sole speaker for this week's congregational sermon, and the community has publicized their topic.
Story: I stared at the code review comments piling up in my inbox, each one pointing out performance issues in the new feature I’d spent the week building. My team expected clean, efficient code, and the launch was scheduled for Monday. I knew I needed to refactor, but the clock was ticking toward Friday noon. My phone buzzed with a reminder: I was the sole imam for today’s khutbah, and the community had already shared the topic I’d chosen—people would be coming with expectations, some even traveling from neighboring towns. I glanced at my half-finished sermon notes, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. My manager’s Slack message blinked insistently, asking for an update. At the same time, I pictured the congregation gathering, waiting for words of guidance and inspiration. My mind raced, torn between the responsibility to my team and the trust of my community, knowing I couldn’t give less than my best to either.
